perturbation.original_text:
ELEPHANT TALK shall pay all invoices no later than *** after the invoice date. ELEPHANT TALK ***, in the event that ELEPHANT
TALK fails to meet ***
perturbation.changed_text:
ELEPHANT TALK shall pay all invoices at T-Mobile's discretion after the invoice date. ELEPHANT TALK ***, in the event that ELEPHANT
TALK fails to meet ***
perturbation.explanation: The modification removes the clear deadline for invoice payments, replacing it with a discretionary timeline determined by T-Mobile. This is contradictory because Dutch law requires specific and reasonable payment terms to be established in commercial contracts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Article 6:119a of the Dutch Civil Code (Burgerlijk Wetboek) regarding payment terms in commercial contracts.

perturbation.original_text:
Any claim for damages must be notified to the other Party within six (6) months as from the date on which the damage was caused, failing
which such claim is deemed to be waived.
perturbation.changed_text:
Any claim for damages must be notified to the other Party within one (1) month as from the date on which the damage was caused, failing
which such claim is deemed to be waived.
perturbation.explanation: The modification reduces the notification period for damage claims to one month. This may be considered unreasonably short under Dutch law, particularly for complex damages, potentially conflicting with principles of reasonableness and fairness in contract law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Article 6:248 of the Dutch Civil Code (Burgerlijk Wetboek), which emphasizes reasonableness and fairness in contractual relationships.

perturbation.original_text:
If the force majeure event continues for more than two (2) consecutive calendar weeks, then the Parties shall promptly meet and discuss
methods to resolve the difficulties arising from the event of force majeure. If no agreement is reached by the Parties within a period of
fifteen(15) Calendar Days and the force majeure event continues to have a substantial effect on the performance of the Agreement, either
Party shall have the right to terminate this Agreement in whole or in part with immediate effect by written notice without incurring any
financial liability to the other Party as a consequence of such termination.
perturbation.changed_text: If the force majeure event continues for more than ten (10) calendar days, then T-Mobile reserves the right to terminate this Agreement in whole or in part with immediate effect by written notice without incurring any financial liability to the other Party as a consequence of such termination.
perturbation.explanation: The change permits T-Mobile to terminate the agreement due to force majeure after only 10 days without requiring discussion or negotiation. While force majeure clauses are generally accepted, Dutch law emphasizes fairness. Giving T-Mobile the sole right to terminate quickly without good-faith negotiation could be deemed unreasonable, especially for a long-term agreement with substantial investment.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Article 6:248 of the Dutch Civil Code (Burgerlijk Wetboek), related to the requirements of reasonableness and fairness in contract execution. Also general principles of good faith.
